abstract.text: A container view controller that manages navigation between pages of content, where a subview controller manages each page.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Page view controller–navigation can be controlled programmatically by your app or directly by the user using gestures. When navigating from page to page, the page view controller uses the transition that you specify to animate the change.
class provides only a way to swipe between full-screen content pages. Unlike in iOS, a user cannot interact with or move focus between items on each page.

When defining a page view controller interface, you can provide the content view controllers one at a time (or two at a time, depending upon the spine position and double-sided state) or as-needed using a data source. When providing content view controllers one at a time, you use the
method to set the current content view controllers. To support gesture-based navigation, you must provide your view controllers using a data source object.
The data source for a page view controller is responsible for providing the content view controllers on demand and must conform to the
protocol. The delegate object—an object that conforms to the
protocol—provides some appearance-related information and receives notifications about gesture-initiated transitions.
This class is generally used as-is, but can also be subclassed.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The base class for concrete gesture recognizers.
Navigational controls that display in a bar along the top of the screen, usually in conjunction with a navigation controller.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
The items that a navigation bar displays when the associated view controller is visible.
A container view controller that manages navigation between pages of content, where a subview controller manages each page.
Directions for page-turn transitions.
Orientations for page-turn transitions.
Keys for creating the page view controller.
Locations for the spine.
Styles for the page-turn transition.
The object that provides view controllers.
The delegate object.
An array of
objects that are configured to handle user interaction.
Creates a page view controller from data in an unarchiver.
Initializes a newly created page view controller.
A Boolean value that indicates whether content appears on the back of pages.
The direction along which navigation occurs.
Sets the view controllers to be displayed.
The location of the spine.
The style used to transition between view controllers.
The view controllers displayed by the page view controller.
The
protocol is adopted by an object that provides view controllers to the page view controller on an as-needed basis, in response to navigation gestures.
The delegate of a page view controller must adopt the

protocol. These methods allow the delegate to receive a notification when the device orientation changes and when the user navigates to a new page. For page-curl style transitions, the delegate can provide a different spine location in response to a change in the interface orientation.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A tab subclass that represents the system’s search tab.
A container view controller that implements a hierarchical interface.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
An object that manages a tab in a tab bar.
A control that displays one or more buttons in a tab bar for selecting between different subtasks, views, or modes in an app.
A container view controller that manages a multiselection interface, where the selection determines which child view controller to display.
An object that describes an item in a tab bar.
An object that manages a collection of tab objects.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Create a composite interface by combining content from one or more view controllers with other custom views.

abstract.text: Build your app’s user interface from view controllers, and change the currently visible view controller when you want to display new content.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Managing content in your app’s windows

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
